p: Pathways in amino acid metabolism, particularly in tryptophan [ 5, 6] and branched-chain amino acids [ 7, 8], may contribute to PD pathogenesis. Several genetic variants potentially involved in amino acid metabolic pathways, such as aminocarboxymuconate semialdehyde decarboxylase- ( ACMSD-) transmembrane protein 163 ( TMEM163) rs6430538, methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase 1 ( MCCC1) rs12637471, branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase kinase- ( BCKDK-) syntaxin 1B ( STX1B) rs14235, were listed on the top risk loci by meta-analysis of GWAS in Caucasian [ 3, 9]. However, these genetic associations in Han Chinese are limitedly revealed. To provide more facts about amino acid metabolism genetic loci contributing to PD across different populations, we conducted a case-control study by examining the genotypic and allelic frequencies of ACMSD- TMEM163 rs6430538, MCCC1 rs12637471, and BCKDK- STX1B rs14235 in 599 Taiwanese PD patients and 598 control subjects.
